question: מה שייכות אבילות ציון וירושלים לענין העגלות

matched_passages.passage: וכמו"כ ביוסף ע"י שנתאמת להם ע"י ראיית המילה שהוא צדיק, מעתה האמינו בו באות הדיבור שדיבר בלה"ק, וגם שהיה דיבורו נראית לחוש הראות, אבל באות לבד אי אפשר להאמין בו שאפשר שיעשה האות בכישוף ובלט כמ"ש הרמב"ם ז"ל, ומעתה אין ראיה מכאן דב' סימנים אמצעיים מהני בכל מקום כמו סימן מובהק, דאפשר דלא מהני במקום אחר, ורק כאן האמינו לו בב' סימנים, דע"י שראו בו שהוא צדיק האמינו בו עפ"י האותות, כמו שמצות התורה להאמין ע"י חזקה אם הוא מוחזק לגדול וחכם, ובאופן זה הבטחה הוא לנו שיתאמת הנביא לעולם ומן השמים אין מניחים אותו לשקר באופן זה, ע"כ סמכו השבטים על ב' סימנים אלו, ועוד דכאן היו הסימנים ברורים ומובהקים, דראי' ברורה על צדקתו ממה שהראה להם שהוא מהול. וראו השראת השם השורה עליו, ומראיית הלשון נתברר להם שכפיו כן לבו ואינו משנה בדיבורו אפילו לשם שמים כנ"ל, ואם כן היו הסימנים ברורים ומובהקים ע"כ סמכו עליהם השבטים, אבל אין ראיה מכאן על סימנים שאינם מובהקים, ולא יקשה מכאן על שיטת החולקים על המשאת בנימין הנ"ל.

Similarly with Yosef, once they verified through seeing his milah (circumcision) that he was a tzaddik (righteous person), they then believed in the sign of his speech when he spoke in Lashon Hakodesh (the Holy Tongue/Hebrew). Also, his speech was visible to the physical sense of sight. However, one cannot believe in a sign alone, as it's possible to perform signs through kishuf (sorcery) and magic, as the Rambam z"l wrote.

Therefore, there is no proof from here that two intermediate simanim (signs) are effective everywhere like a distinct siman muvhak (clear sign), as it's possible they wouldn't be effective elsewhere. Here they only believed him because of two signs: since they saw he was a tzaddik, they believed him based on the signs, similar to how the Torah commands us to believe based on a chazakah (presumption) if someone is established as great and wise.

In this way, we have assurance that a navi (prophet) will always be verified, and from Heaven they won't allow him to lie in this manner. Therefore, the tribes relied on these two signs. Furthermore, here the signs were clear and distinct - there was clear proof of his righteousness from showing them he was circumcised, and they saw the Divine Presence resting upon him. From seeing his language, it became clear to them that his mouth and heart were aligned, and he wouldn't change his speech even for the sake of Heaven, as mentioned above.

Therefore, since the signs were clear and distinct, the tribes relied upon them. However, there is no proof from here regarding signs that aren't distinct, and this doesn't pose a difficulty to those who disagree with the Masas Binyamin mentioned above.

matched_passages.passage: ומעתה בהתודע אל אחיו ואמר להם אני יוסף העוד אבי חי וגו'. הנה היה מקום לאחיו שיתמהו עליו ויפקפקו בהאמנת דבריו, דאלו הי' האמת כדבריו איך יתכן שסבל כ"כ שנים צער אביו ולא הודיעו, אחרי שהיה סיפק בידו להודיעו שהיה מלך ומושל ומי יאמר לו מה תעשה, גם איך לא הרגיש באהבת האחו' עד הנה וציער אותם בכל מיני עלילות של חינם, ע"כ הצטדק עצמו לפניהם וא"ל עיניכם הרואות כי פי המדבר אליכם, וכבחי' שכתב המאור ושמש ז"ל, שאתם רואים שאיני מדבר אלא דיבורים שנשלחו לי מן השמים. ולא אני המדבר אלא פי מדבר ברצון הבוי"ת ע"י ששכינה מדברת מגרוני, ומעתה אל תתמהו על כ"ז, כי היה רצון הבוי"ת וסיבה מן השמים, והושמו בפי ברוה"ק כל אלה הדיבורים, ומה שלא היה רצון הבוי"ת לא דברתי. וע"כ לא הודעתי לאבי, וקבלו השבטים דבריו שראו אמיתתם כי בהתודע אל אחיו נתגלה להם פנימיותו ומדריגתו מה שהיה נסתר ומכוסה מהם במשך כל הזמן עד עכשיו.

Now when he made himself known to his brothers and said to them "I am Yosef, is my father still alive, etc." His brothers could have been puzzled and doubted the truthfulness of his words, for if his words were true, how could he have endured his father's pain for so many years without informing him, especially since he had the ability to do so as he was king and ruler, and who could question his actions? Also, how did he not feel brotherly love until now and caused them distress with all kinds of baseless accusations?

Therefore, he justified himself before them saying "Your eyes see that it is my mouth speaking to you," as explained by the Maor VaShemesh, that "you see that I speak only words that were sent to me from Heaven. It is not I who speaks, but rather my mouth speaks with the will of the Blessed Creator (Borei Yisbarach) through the Shechinah (Divine Presence) speaking from my throat. Therefore, do not be puzzled by all this, as it was the will of the Blessed Creator and a cause from Heaven, and all these words were placed in my mouth through Ruach HaKodesh (Divine Spirit), and what was not the will of the Blessed Creator, I did not speak. This is why I did not inform my father."

The tribes (brothers) accepted his words as they saw their truth, for when he revealed himself to his brothers, his inner essence and spiritual level were revealed to them, which had been hidden and concealed from them throughout all this time until now.

matched_passages.passage: וכתב הכלי יקר (פרשת תצא) עה"פ לא יהיה לך בכיסך אבן ואבן וגו' שמדבר הפסוק בא' שקרי ואחד אמיתי, והורה שגם הישר נקרא תועבה, לפי שהאבן הישרה גורמת לו לשקול בשקרות וכו', והרי לכך הוא מחזיק הישרה כדי לאמת שקר שלו, לכך גם הישרה תועבה וכו' עיי"ש, וכמו כן מו שפוסח על שתו הסעיפים הוא גרוע יותר מעובד עבודה זרה בגלוי, כי על ידי שמתנהג במקצת ככשרים, על ידי זה הוא מסית את בני האדם ומפתה אותם לטעות אחריו וחושבים אותו לצדיק, מה שאין כן העובד עבודה זרה בגלוי אין מי שיטעה בו. ובזה יתיישב הענין כי מתחלה חשב יהודה שיוסף שר מצרי ע"כ אמר לו הננו עבדים לאדוני גם אנחנו וגו', דהנה ידעו מגזירת הגלות שמוכרחים להיות בגלות אצל אומות העולם וקבלו גזירת הבוי"ת שמו באהבה, אבל אחר שראה את יוסף מדבר כאיש יהודי שומר תורה ומצות ואמר חלילה לי לעשות היפך התורה, ולעומת זאת בדינו של בנימין רצה לדון בדיני מצרים, נמצא שהוא כפוסח על שתו סעיפים. ועל כן לא קבל יהודה להיות בגלות אצל איש כזה, ועל כן לחם יהודה נגדו לבטל גזירתו.

The Kli Yakar (in Parshat Teitzei) writes on the verse "You shall not have in your pocket a weight and a weight" that the verse speaks of one false and one true weight, and teaches that even the accurate weight is called an abomination, because the accurate weight enables him to use false weights, etc. For he keeps the accurate weight in order to validate his false one, therefore even the accurate weight is an abomination, etc.

Similarly, one who "wavers between two positions" [poseiach al shtei ha'seifim] is worse than someone who openly worships idols, because by conducting himself partially like the righteous, he misleads people and entices them to err after him as they consider him righteous, unlike the open idol worshiper whom no one will mistake.

This explains the matter: Initially, Yehudah thought Yosef was an Egyptian minister, therefore he said to him "We will be slaves to my master, we too..." For they knew of the decree of exile that they must be in exile among the nations of the world, and they accepted Hashem's decree with love. However, after seeing Yosef speaking like a Jewish man who observes Torah and mitzvot, saying "God forbid that I should act against the Torah," yet regarding Binyamin's judgment wanting to judge according to Egyptian law - thus he was "wavering between two positions." Therefore, Yehudah refused to be in exile under such a person, and thus fought against Yosef to nullify his decree.

matched_passages.passage: ועתה נבוא לבאר ענין העגלות. דהנה כתב השביבי נוגה דהזוה"ק והמדרש פליגי. דבמדרש מבואר דעגלות פרעה הי' ע"ז חקוקה עליהם ועמד יהודה ושרפן, ובזוה"ק מבואר דאלין ואלין אתו לות יעקב עכת"ד. אמנם אפשר להשוות דבריהם ואלו ואלו דא"ח ולא פליגי, ונאמר דהנה ממשמעות הפסוקים מוכח כדברי הזוה"ק דעגלות יוסף ועגלות פרעה שניהם באו אל יעקב, שנאמר וירא את העגלות אשר שלח יוסף, וכתיב וישאו בנ"י את נשיהם ואת טפם בעגלות אשר שלח פרעה וגו', ואם עגלות של פרעה נשרפו במקומן א"כ האיך נשאו בהן את נשיהם ואת טפם, אלא ע"כ נצטרך לומר לפי דברי המדרש שאחר ששרפן יהודה שלח פרעה עגלות אחרים, ואותן עגלות הגיעו ליעקב, ומעתה עגלות פרעה שנזכרו בפסוק הן היו העגלות השניות שהגיעו אל יעקב, ורומזים אל העתיד כמ"ש לעיל בשם ספר אור החמה, וכמו שסיים בזוה"ק כד יפקין מן גלותא והביאו את כל אחיכם מנחה לה', שאומות העולם יביאו את ישראל מארצות גלותם בעגלותיהם מנחה לה', והשניים לא היו של ע"ז, והם פועל דמיוני על העתיד, ולעתיד לבוא ודאי לא יביאו את ישראל על עגלות של עבודה זרה, ומ"ש במדרש שהעגלות אשר שלח פרעה עמד יהודה ושרפן אלו היו אשר שלח ראשונה, וגם הזוה"ק יסבור כן, אלא שאין הזוה"ק מזכירם להדיא שגם בפסוק לא הוזכרו עגלות אלו לא שליחתן ולא שריפתן, אלא שהי' מקובל לחז"ל ששלח פרעה עגלות של ע"ז ושרפן יהודה, ומכיון שלא הזכירן הכתוב, גם הזוה"ק לא הזכירם, אבל לפי האמת הזוה"ק והמדרש לא פליגי כלל ואידי ואידי מודים שאותן של ע"ז עמד יהודה ושרפן, ושלח פרעה אחרות ואותן הגיע אל יעקב והם פועל דמיוני אל עגלות דלעתיד כנ"ל.

Here's the English translation, preserving the Hasidic terminology:

Now let us explain the matter of the wagons. The Shevivei Nogah writes that the Zohar HaKadosh and the Midrash disagree. The Midrash explains that Pharaoh's wagons had idolatrous images engraved on them, and Yehudah stood up and burned them. However, in the Zohar HaKadosh it's explained that both these and those came to Yaakov.

However, it's possible to reconcile their words, and "these and these are the words of the living G-d" (eilu v'eilu divrei Elokim chaim), and they don't actually disagree. We can say that from the verses' implications, it's proven like the Zohar's words that both Yosef's wagons and Pharaoh's wagons came to Yaakov, as it's written "and he saw the wagons that Yosef sent," and it's written "and the Children of Israel carried their wives and children in the wagons that Pharaoh sent." If Pharaoh's wagons were burned in their place, how could they have carried their wives and children in them?

Therefore, we must say according to the Midrash that after Yehudah burned them, Pharaoh sent other wagons, and those wagons reached Yaakov. From now on, Pharaoh's wagons mentioned in the verse were the second set that reached Yaakov, and they allude to the future as mentioned above in the name of the Sefer Ohr HaChamah, and as the Zohar concludes when they will leave exile, "and they will bring all your brothers as an offering to Hashem" - that the nations of the world will bring Israel from their lands of exile in their wagons as an offering to Hashem. The second set of wagons were not associated with idolatry, and they serve as a prophetic model for the future. In the future, they certainly won't bring Israel on wagons associated with avodah zarah (idolatry).

What's written in the Midrash about Yehudah burning the wagons that Pharaoh sent refers to those sent initially, and the Zohar would agree with this, except that the Zohar doesn't mention them explicitly since these wagons aren't mentioned in the verse - neither their sending nor their burning. Rather, it was a tradition among Chazal that Pharaoh sent wagons with idolatrous images and Yehudah burned them. Since the verse doesn't mention them, the Zohar doesn't mention them either. But in truth, the Zohar and Midrash don't disagree at all, and both agree that those with idolatrous images were burned by Yehudah, and Pharaoh sent others which reached Yaakov and serve as a prophetic model for the future wagons as mentioned above.

matched_passages.passage: ואפ"ל בדרך הפשוט. כו מתחילה קבלו על עצמם דין שמים באהבה, בהיותם חושבים כי כבר הגיע הזמן לפרוע שטר חוב של גזירת ידוע תדע, ולזה אמרו גם אנחנו נהי' עבדים וגו', ע"ז השיב להם שלוחו של יוסף גם עתה כדבריכם כן הוא, שהאמת כדבריכם, וכבר הגיע הזמן שתהיו עבדים למצרים, אבל חלילה לי מעשות זאת כו איננו רוצה להסב שתהי' ירידתכם בגלות באופן מבוזה וע"י עלילה, רק שיסבב הגוזר יתברך ותתקיים הגזירה באופן אחר. כאמרז"ל ראוי היה יעקב אבינו לירד למצרים בשלשלאות של ברזל אלא שזכותו גרמה לו, והנה בעוחום היו השבטים הק', דכ"ז שיהיו כולם בצוותא חדא אין שום אומה ולשון שולט בהם ויתקיימו בקדושתן ולא היו מתיראים מקליפות מצרים, אבל עכשיו שרצה יוסף שרק בנימין לבדו יהיה עבד במצרים וכולם ישובו אל אביהם, חשו מפני הסכנה פן יקראנו אסון בארץ הטמאה ערות הארץ ולטעם זה ניגש יהודה לדבר אתו קשות.

One can explain in a simple way: Initially, they accepted the heavenly decree with love, thinking that the time had come to pay the debt of the decree of "You shall surely know" [referring to the prophecy of exile given to Avraham]. Therefore, they said "We too shall be servants, etc." To this, Yosef's messenger responded "Now too, it is as you say" - meaning that they spoke truth, and indeed the time had arrived for them to be servants in Egypt.

However, "Heaven forbid that I should do this" - he did not want to cause their descent into exile to happen in a disgraceful way through a false accusation. Rather, the Divine decree should be fulfilled in another manner. As our Sages said: "Yaakov our father was meant to descend to Egypt in iron chains, but his merit caused [it to happen differently]."

Now the holy Shevatim (tribes) were concerned, for as long as they remained together as one, no nation or tongue could rule over them and they would maintain their kedushah (holiness) without fear of the klipot (impure forces) of Egypt. But now that Yosef wanted only Binyamin alone to be a servant in Egypt while they all returned to their father, they feared the danger that harm might befall him in the impure land, the ervat ha'aretz (nakedness of the land). For this reason, Yehudah approached to speak harshly with him.

matched_passages.passage: ובזה יתבארו דברי הזוה"ק בפרשת העגלות, מה שהקדים לביאור פרשה זו, ענין אבילות ציון וירושלים כנ"ל, ר"ח פתח וכו' שישו אתה משוש כל המתאבלים עליה, והולך ומבאר אבילות החורבן, ולכאורה מה שייכא ענינה לפרשת עגלות, אמנם יעקב אבינו ע"ה ויוסף והשבטים בעת הזאת שעשו הכנה לירידתן למצרים, לקבל עליהם עול הגלות גזרת ברית בין הבתרים שזה הי' שורש כל הגליות, המה ראו ברוח קדשם כל הגליות וחורבן בית המקדש והתאבלו עלי', כמ"ש ויפול על צוארי בנימין אחיו ויבך, פירש"י על ב' מקדשות שעתידין להיות בחלקו וסופן ליחרב, ע"כ ראו להמשיך ישועה ותיקון במה שעשו פועל דמיוני ופעולת ההכנה, להקל מעליהם עול הגלות, ולהכין להם דרך שיושלם התיקון הנרצה בגלות על ידיהם, ופעולת הכנה זו נרמז בעגלות יוסף כאשר פירשנו לעיל, ע"כ הקדים בזוה"ק ענין אבילות ציון וירושלים לביאור פרשת עגלות, שעל ידי שראו והשיגו ענין האבילות ההוא והחורבן הנורא, הכינו רפואה ותיקון הנרמז בענין העגלות כנ"ל.

Here's the English translation, preserving the Hasidic terminology:

And with this, the words of the holy Zohar regarding the wagons (agalot) passage can be explained - why it prefaced the explanation of this passage with the matter of mourning for Tzion and Yerushalayim, as mentioned above, "Rabbi Chiya began etc., 'Rejoice with her in joy, all who mourn for her.'" It proceeds to explain the mourning for the destruction, and at first glance, what connection does this have to the passage about the wagons?

However, our father Yaakov (peace be upon him), Yosef, and the tribes, at this time when they were preparing for their descent to Mitzrayim, to accept upon themselves the yoke of exile - the decree of the Covenant Between the Parts, which was the root of all exiles - they saw with their ruach hakodesh (divine inspiration) all the future exiles and the destruction of the Beit HaMikdash, and they mourned for it. As it is written, "And he fell upon his brother Binyamin's neck and wept" - Rashi explains this refers to the two Temples that were destined to be in his portion and would ultimately be destroyed.

Therefore, they saw fit to draw down salvation and tikkun (rectification) through what they did as a symbolic act and preparatory action, to ease the burden of exile from themselves, and to prepare a way for the desired tikkun to be completed through them in exile. This preparatory action was alluded to in Yosef's wagons, as we explained above. "And Yehudah approached him, etc., 'and let not your anger burn against your servant, for you are like Pharaoh.' Rashi explains, based on the Midrash, 'You will eventually be stricken with tzara'as (leprosy) just as Pharaoh was stricken because of my grandmother Sarah, who was detained for one night, etc.' Another explanation: 'for you are like Pharaoh' means if you provoke me, I will kill you and your master.

We can explain the verse "to establish for you a remnant in the land, etc." based on what is said in the Gemara regarding ribis (interest) [Bava Metzia 75b]: Those who transgress the negative commandment are the lender, borrower, guarantor, and witnesses. Abaye said the lender transgresses all [prohibitions], etc., while the guarantor and witnesses only transgress "you shall not place upon him interest."

The Gemara [62a] asks: While all others perform an action, what action do the witnesses perform? Rather, is it not that the very act of establishing [the loan] is significant? Thus, even though the guarantor and witnesses didn't perform an actual deed in the matter itself, because the transaction was completed through them, they are liable for the prohibition of "you shall not place," with the root of the action being included in the word "placing."

Similarly, in our matter, Yosef HaTzaddik preceded going to Egypt to prepare a place for Bnei Yisrael so they could maintain their kedushah (holiness) in Egyptian exile, which was the ervat ha'aretz (most defiled land) and extremely contaminated. Through the power of his kedushah and the trials he withstood and overcame, and by becoming ruler over the sar (angel) of Egypt, he weakened the power of tumah (impurity) and klipot (negative forces) at their root.

Through this, Israel merited to be protected from immorality in Egypt - "Bnei Yisrael entered and Bnei Yisrael left" - and not one of them was born from improper relations, as our Sages said. Moreover, Yosef HaTzaddik prepared a power of salvation for future generations until the final exile, so that Israel could overcome and withstand the trials of exile and maintain their kedushah even in the terrible lowliness of ikveta d'meshicha (the footsteps of Mashiach), as the Egyptian exile is the root of all exiles.

The holy Avot and Shevatim were the root of all Jewish souls throughout the generations, and whatever exists in the branch exists in the root. Therefore, through their holy actions, they opened a channel and prepared strength for all generations of Israel. This is the meaning of "to establish for you a remnant in the land and to sustain you for a great deliverance" - that Yosef HaTzaddik established a foundation and root of strength for all generations of Israel. This is the holy spark which is hidden within the nefesh (soul) of every Jew, inherited from our holy forefathers. At first, it is only at the level of a "remnant," but afterward, the boundary of kedushah expands "to sustain you for a great deliverance."

One can explain the verse "Your eyes see... for it is my mouth speaking to you," which Chazal interpret as "as my mouth is, so is my heart." In the previous verse it states "I will sustain you there... for there are yet five years of famine, lest you come to poverty, you, and your household, and all that you have." However, seemingly Yosef's promise to feed and sustain them for five more years wasn't fulfilled, as Chazal say that when Yaakov Avinu came to Egypt, the famine immediately ceased in his merit.

It's possible that Yosef knew through Ruach HaKodesh (Divine inspiration) that the famine would end with Yaakov's arrival, as Chazal say in Pirkei D'Rabbi Eliezer that Ruach HaKodesh guided him from his youth until his death. If so, why did he say "I will sustain you... for five more years of famine" when his vow wasn't fulfilled?

However, we have a principle that one shouldn't rely on miracles. Therefore, Yosef HaTzaddik empathized with their suffering and took upon himself wholeheartedly to feed and sustain them for five years. For this, he already received reward for all five years even though the famine ended earlier, as explained in the aforementioned Sifri that one receives reward for the declaration even if unable to complete the action.

So his brothers wouldn't question how he was permitted to make such a vow, since it's forbidden to make vows except by saying "Harei Zu" (behold this is), we explained earlier that it's permitted with proper intention. Therefore, he immediately said "Your eyes see... my mouth speaking to you," which Chazal interpret as "as my mouth is, so is my heart" - meaning his thoughts and intentions were proper, and in such a case it's a mitzvah to make a vow and one receives reward for the declaration as if for the action.

There are those who think that maintaining a large institution with great expenses through limited means and a small number of God-fearing supporters is anyway miraculous, and therefore rely on miracles, thinking they don't need to take action as the miracle will come regardless. But this isn't correct, as we don't rely on miracles. Only through the power of Jews giving with self-sacrifice and proper intention can we exist beyond natural means.

Let us return to explain the matter of the wagons that Yosef sent, and what our Sages said that he gave him a sign regarding the passage of the eglah arufah (broken-necked heifer), etc. Based on what is written in the Midrash Rabbah (Parshat Vayishlach), Rabbi Yochanan said we are not as expert in the minutiae of avodah zarah (idolatry) as our father Yaakov was.

Certainly, Yosef was also expert in the minutiae of avodah zarah, as Yaakov Avinu had transmitted everything to him, as it is said "for he was a ben zekunim (child of his old age)," and all that he learned from Shem and Ever he transmitted to him. Now, regarding the wagons that Pharaoh sent, our Sages said that they had idolatrous images engraved on them, and Yehudah stood up and burned them. This shows that all of Pharaoh and his people's desire and longing was to insert the root of avodah zarah into the house of Yaakov, which is why Pharaoh sent these wagons.

However, the wagons that Yosef sent were clean of any suspicion or trace of avodah zarah, even from the smallest branch or aspect of idolatry, such as preparation or similar matters that are not directly visible to the eye. For Yosef HaTzaddik was expert in discerning even this, as it is written in the holy Zohar (Parshat Vayishlach): "For our holy forefathers, just as they were expert in the wisdom of the holy Merkavah (Divine Chariot), they were also expert in the wisdom of the external chariots, which is the root of avodah zarah. For God made this opposing that, etc. And being thoroughly expert in these wisdoms, they could perceive and know many minutiae of avodah zarah that depend on various levels, etc."

Therefore, when Yaakov Avinu saw the wagons and recognized them, he knew that Yosef still stood in his righteousness and his level of being able to discern and distance himself even from a trace of avodah zarah. Thus, "vatechi ruach Yaakov" - the spirit of Yaakov was revived.

And this is what the liturgical poet meant [when he wrote] "The holy city and its districts were disgraced and plundered, etc." - from this nothing remained, not even remnants. We have no remnant except this Torah, meaning that from the Torah at least remnants remained for us. Although it's not at the level of perfection that would be above the Beis HaMikdash and all of Israel's precious things - for unfortunately only remnants of the Torah's essential greatness remained - nevertheless, even this is valuable and acceptable before Hashem, given the generation's lowly state, that they at least maintain some remnants of the holy Torah.

Behold, this too comes to us as an inheritance from the holy forefathers, who prayed for us until the end of all generations and created a lasting spiritual impact for all generations after them. Yosef HaTzaddik, with his holy power, prepared strength for all future generations so they could withstand great trials. The holy tribes worked greatly for the sake of future generations until the coming of Mashiach, and through his holy power achieved that even in the lowly generations, at least remnants of the holy Torah would remain and the Torah would not, God forbid, be completely forgotten from Israel.

This is what is meant by "And God sent me before you to establish" - which refers to the power of Torah, as they interpreted through the gezeirah shavah of "establish-establish" as mentioned above. And this means "to establish for you a remnant in the land" - that at least remnants of Torah's power would remain in all generations. And through maintaining these remnants, they will later merit "to sustain you as a great deliverance" at the time of Mashiach's coming, when they will merit the complete power of Torah.

This is hinted at in saying "to sustain you," meaning at the time when there will be "sustaining for you" - which is the time of resurrection when Moshe, Aharon, the generation of the desert, and all the holy tzaddikim will arise. Then there will be a great deliverance, through having maintained the remnants of the holy Torah during the time of lowliness. This explains why the verse begins with "remnant in the land" and concludes with "great deliverance" - for through maintaining the remnants, they will later merit a great deliverance at the time of resurrection, speedily in our days.

This aspect was also present in the Ten Martyrs (Asarah Harugei Malchut), as explained in the writings of the holy Arizal, that the souls of the tzaddikim were transferred into the bodies of those who were punished, in the aspect of exchange and substitution. This concept originates from the ram of Yitzchak, as explained in the Midrash, which is also the aspect of offering a korban (sacrifice) that is considered as if the person offered himself.

Through this, we can understand the words of the Yalkut that Yehudah offered a korban. This means that when Yosef told them "and you go up in peace to your father," he hinted to them about the concept of substitution - that they would not have to suffer the punishment themselves. This is similar to offering a korban, which serves as a substitute for the person. Therefore, Yehudah offered a korban because Yosef taught him this concept through his words "and you go up in peace, etc."

What emerges from this is that the source of offering korbanot comes from our father Yitzchak, as Avraham his father performed a symbolic act for all generations by offering the ram as his substitute. This is why Yaakov our father, peace be upon him, mentioned his father Yitzchak when offering korbanot, to awaken this aspect - that the source of korbanot is from Yitzchak. Therefore, specifically "he offered sacrifices to the God of his father Yitzchak."

This explains the aforementioned Midrash "They said to him 'the peace' of all has been poured out." Meaning, the peace that you are alluding to regarding the Ten Martyrs (Asarah Harugei Malchut) is a peace of darkness and gloom and terrible decree. Yet the Ruach HaKodesh (Divine Spirit) calls out "Great peace have they who love Your Torah, and there is no stumbling block for them," because in the end they will have peace and the punishment will not actually befall them. Rather, their punishment will be cleansed through their being seized and their judgment being sealed, as stated in the aforementioned Pirkei Heichalot.

However, the Ruach HaKodesh was not revealed to them, because if it had been, they would not have experienced anguish at their judgment and their sin would not have been cleansed. Perhaps when Yehudah said "there is blindness here," he prophesied without knowing it - that even Yosef's words "and you shall go up in peace to your father," which alludes to the decree of the Ten Martyrs, is merely a blindness, to cleanse their punishment through the anguish of the decree without it actually being fulfilled, as mentioned above. But he did not fully grasp his own prophecy, so that they would not know of their salvation and their sin would be atoned through the anguish of the decree and through their having tasted the taste of death, as mentioned above.
